qas.question: Who was the founder of Philadelphia sports corporation Spectator?
Comcast's purchase of Spectator gave them what sports teams in Philadelphia?

answers.text: the Philadelphia Flyers NHL hockey team, the Philadelphia 76ers National Basketball Association basketball team

qas.question: What was the original name of NBCSN?
What was the second name NBCSN was known as?
Comcast bought naming rights for what college's basketball arena?
What did Spectacor buy from Comcast?
What was the original name of the Golf Channel?
How much did Comcast pay Spectacor for the controlling stake?
What did Comcast rename the Philadelphia 76ers basketball arena in 2014?

context: In 1996, Comcast bought a <b6_0>controlling stake<b6_0/> in Spectacor from the company's founder, <a0_0><b5_0>Ed Snider<b5_0/><a0_0/>. Comcast-Spectacor holdings now include <a1_0>the Philadelphia Flyers NHL hockey team, the Philadelphia 76ers National Basketball Association basketball team<a1_0/> and two large multipurpose arenas in Philadelphia. Over a number of years, Comcast became majority owner of Comcast SportsNet, as well as Golf Channel and NBCSN (formerly the <a2_0><b7_0>Outdoor Life Network<b7_0/><a2_0/>, then <a3_0>Versus<a3_0/>). In 2002, Comcast paid <a4_0>the University of Maryland<a4_0/> <b8_0>$25 million<b8_0/> for naming rights to the new basketball arena built on the College Park campus, the XFINITY Center. Before it was renamed for Comcast's cable subsidiary, <b9_0>XFINITY Center<b9_0/> was called Comcast Center from its opening in 2002 through July 2014.
